newsitem.title: USA: Cable TV could gain from digital TV - US FCC chief.
newsitem.headline: Cable TV could gain from digital TV - US FCC chief.

text.p: Cable television may have a chance to win over viewers and advertisers from broadcast TV if broadcasters do not pursue high-definition digital TV, the head of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday.

"I'm beginning to wonder if broadcasters really want these DTV licenses," FCC Chairman Reed Hundt told a convention of the National Cable Television Association in New Orleans, referring to the digital TV licenses the FCC is set to award TV stations.

Hundt said that as long as TV stations believe the future of broadcast TV is analog transmission, "they are putting the 'franchise' up for grabs. So what an opportunity cable has to grab the franchise away."
Hundt said the franchise refers to the "core package of the most popular TV channels and the most popular way to deliver them."

Hundt has called on TV broadcasters to begin digital transmission -- which offers crystal-clear images and CD-quality sound -- within a year in selected major markets, once stations get the DTV licenses.
Broadcasters say more time is needed.
"I'm beginning to wonder if broadcasters really want these DTV licesnes," Hundt said.
"If broadcsaters won't launch digital television quickly, then DTV is going to be a failure," he added.

"Before long a huge majority of TV sets will definitely be receiving digital TV. Satellite is there. Cable is on its way -- moving to digital faster as (satellite TV) poses more of a threat. If broadcasters wait, it'll be too late," Hundt said.
